title: 106_hr4544
content: The Act may be cited as the "Federalization of Crimes Uniform Standards Act of 2000". Congress recognizes the intertwined system of State and Federal courts in the US, with State courts handling criminal trials and Federal courts having limited jurisdiction in criminal matters to complement State courts. There is no valid reason for maintaining two separate justice systems. Citizens should not be subject to different justice systems with varying penalties and the possibility of being tried multiple times for the same offense. The text chunk "SEC. 3. COMMISSION TO REVIEW THE FEDERAL CRIMINAL CODE." is a concise statement about the establishment of a commission to review the federal criminal code. This follows the idea that citizens should not face different justice systems and penalties, or be tried multiple times for the same offense. The Commission to Review the Federal Criminal Code is established with the duty to prepare law enforcement impact statements, review federal criminal offenses, and carry out other activities as outlined in the Act. The Commission is composed of 5 members appointed by the President pro tempore of the Senate, the minority leader of the Senate, and the Speaker of the House. The Commission to Review the Federal Criminal Code consists of 5 members appointed by various officials, with disqualification for US officers or employees. Each member serves a 5-year term, vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and members are paid at the rate of level IV of the Executive Schedule. The Commission to Review the Federal Criminal Code consists of 5 members appointed by various officials, with disqualification for US officers or employees. Each member serves a 5-year term, vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and members are paid at the rate of level IV of the Executive Schedule. Members receive travel expenses, a quorum consists of 3 members, the Chairperson is appointed by the Chief Justice of the United States, and the Commission shall have a director appointed by the Chairperson. The Director of the Commission may appoint additional personnel as needed, subject to rules set by the Commission. The Director and staff shall be appointed in accordance with title 5, United States Code, and paid based on General Schedule pay rates. The Commission has the power to hold hearings, take testimony, and receive evidence as necessary to carry out its duties. The Commission has the authority to administer oaths, establish rules for its proceedings, and obtain official data from government departments. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission. The Commission can request information from government agencies, except in cases that threaten national security, individual safety, or ongoing investigations. The Commission has the authority to administer oaths, establish rules for its proceedings, and obtain official data from government departments. The Administrator of General Services will provide administrative support services upon request. The Commission will submit an initial report to Congress within 4 years of the Act's enactment, detailing Federal criminal offenses subject to section 6. The Commission will submit a report to Congress within 4 years of the enactment of each Federal criminal offense subject to section 6, containing findings on the offense's relevance to core Federal responsibilities and the inadequacy of State efforts in addressing its purposes. The Commission will submit a report to Congress within 4 years of the enactment of each Federal criminal offense subject to section 6, highlighting the offense's impact on the Federal court system. Section 14(a)(2)(B) of the Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the Commission. SEC. 4. CONTROLS ON CERTAIN FEDERAL CRIMINAL LEGISLATION. The text chunk discusses the requirement for a Federal law enforcement impact statement to accompany any measure increasing the law enforcement responsibilities of the Federal Government. It also outlines the rulemaking powers of the Senate and the House of Representatives in enacting these provisions. The section allows either House to change rules regarding measures, similar to other rules, and applies to consideration of measures one year after the Act's enactment. SEC. 5. FEDERAL LAW ENFORCEMENT IMPACT STATEMENT. The Commission is required to prepare a Federal law enforcement impact statement for measures provided by Senators, Representatives, or committees, detailing the extent to which an increase in law enforcement responsibilities would only affect core Federal responsibilities. The Commission prepares a Federal law enforcement impact statement for measures to determine the extent of impact on core Federal responsibilities, inadequacies in State efforts, and the burden on the Federal court system. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, definitions include the Commission, Director, measure, and core Federal responsibilities related to enforcing offenses against the Federal Government or its entities. The curr_chunk discusses the need for uniform Federal law enforcement in cases involving interstate or international activities that are too complex for individual states to handle effectively, or in situations that impact national interests or constitutional rights.
